Safety ratings: Coupe: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, head restraints & seats), marginal (small overlap front), Convertible: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Auxiliary port for portable audio players
Notable standard features on this model: Power windows with one-touch function, leatherette upholstery, leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel, Bluetooth connectivity, three-color ambient lighting
Notable options on this model: Rearview camera, panoramic sunroof, leather upholstery, remote keyless entry and remote start, premium audio system, navigation
You might also be considering: Audi A3, Fiat 500, Mini Cooper, Nissan Juke

Two developments in the 2015 Volkswagen Beetle lineup merit attention. One is the addition of the Beetle Classic, a value-priced offering in both coupe and convertible form. This least expensive Beetle ($21,515 coupe, $26,415 convertible) takes the standard features of the 1.8T and is then outfitted with a navigation system, a six-speed automatic transmission, and retro-style 17-inch wheels. Inside, it has two-tone leatherette and checked-cloth seats for a look that’s indeed classic. The Beetle Classic can be chosen in white, black, or silver. The second newsworthy item is the new diesel engine, the very latest from Volkswagen’s engineers. It makes an additional 10 horsepower and gets a 2 mpg fuel economy bump on the highway. With 236 pound-feet of torque available at just 1750 rpm—that’s 14 percent greater than the even high-output gasoline turbo engine in the Beetle R-Line—it provides lots of stomp. Also this year, a rearview camera is standard on all but the base versions of the 1.8T, Beetle Classic, and R-Line. A blind-spot monitor and rear traffic alert are available across the lineup. Each of the four models—1.8T, Classic, R-Line, and TDI—is available as a coupe or convertible. The beauty of a Beetle is the combination of heritage, sportiness, and utility while still pulling off a modern look all its own.

New for 2015

2.0-liter turbo-diesel engine, limited-edition Beetle Classic.

subTitle: Cheeky younger sibling.
promoTeaserSmall: Cheeky younger sibling.
promoTeaser: Cheeky younger sibling.
metaKeywords: 2015 Kia Sportage; Kia; SUV; sport-utility; crossover; Korean

pageElements.text:
Type: SUV/crossover
Price range: $22,795–$30,495 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, EX, SX
Engines: 2.4-liter four cylinder, 180/182 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 260 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): FWD: 21/28; AWD: 19/26 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Institute for Highway Safety: Poor (small overlap front), good (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, head restraints & seats); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating (AWD), 4/5 overall rating (FWD)
Our favorite standard feature: 17-inch alloy wheels
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth connectivity, Apple USB compatibility, solar glass, keyless entry, automatic transmission, tilt-and-telescope steering wheel
Notable options on this model: 18-inch wheels, pushbutton start, UVO eServices with rearview camera
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Trax, Ford Escape, Honda CR-V,

The smaller sibling of the Sorento has evolved from a tiny box to a sleek envelope. Rather than being cheap and squeaky, it now carries itself with dignity but can also carry a price tag in the mid-$30,000 range. The Sportage LX and EX share the direct-injection 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine and six-speed automatic transmission, while the uplevel SX has the more powerful, turbocharged direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder. All-wheel drive is available throughout the lineup. The LX is well-equipped with solar glass to keep the interior cooler, a tilt-and-telescoping steering wheel, and Bluetooth connectivity, among other standard features. The EX rides on 18-inch wheels, adds standard fog lamps, a cooling glove box, and UVO eServices infotainment with rearview camera. A panoramic sunroof and power-folding outside mirrors can be ordered. Heated front seats are standard in the EX, with ventilated front seats optional. LED daytime running lamps and tail lamps, and unique 18-inch wheels and radiator grille distinguish the SX. Voice-activated navigation and a smart key with pushbutton start are standard. For those tricky offroad obstacles, downhill brake control joins the suite of electronic chassis controls that’s standard in all models. Rear park assist is optional in the EX and standard in the SX.

New for 2015

New standard features for the SX include smart key and pushbutton start, power folding outside mirrors, and navigation.

title: 2015 Kia Soul
subTitle: Quirky and good to drive.
promoTeaserSmall: Quirky and good to drive.
promoTeaser: Quirky and good to drive.

pageElements.text:
Type: Hatchback
Price range: $16,015–$36,525 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Soul, Soul Plus, Soul Exclaim, Soul EV, Soul EV Plus
Engines: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 130 horsepower; 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 164 horsepower
Transmissions: 6-speed manual, 6-speed automatic, or single-speed (EV)
Fuel economy (mpg): 1.6: 24/30; 2.0 automatic: 23/31; 2.0-liter, automatic with ISG: 24/31; EV: 120/92 (city/highway; mpg-e)
Safety ratings: Institute for Highway Safety: Top safety pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth connectivity
Notable standard features on this model: Stability control, brake assist, hill-start assist, 60/40 split-folding rear seat, FlexSteer selectable steering assist
Notable options on this model: 18-inch wheels, panoramic sunroof with power-operated sunshade, LED tail lamps, pulsating speaker lights
You might also be considering: Fiat 500, Ford Fiesta, Mini Cooper,

The Kia Soul is a joy to drive, you will never lose it in a parking lot, and people will always want to ask you about it. Proving way more popular than expected after being released in 2009, the Soul brings a quirky kind of custom to the low-price arena. It was extensively revised for 2014, and the result was astonishing. The little runabout has a more solid feel and significantly improved ride and handling. Partly due to a stronger body, the vehicle is quieter. Kia spent some money to upgrade the interior, so it grew more attractive and interesting, with more comfortable seats and greater front legroom. The body’s front and rear were redone, adding drama, and the designers really smacked one out of the park when creating the Soul Exclaim’s cool new high-tech LED tail lamps. For the price, you’ll be surprised by the feature content, with an available heated and ventilated front seats and an infotainment system with excellent Android-based navigation display. The larger direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder packs enough wallop to make this light-middleweight quite entertaining on a back road. For 2015, the Soul EV joined the lineup. Its 90-kilowatt battery can deliver up to 93 miles of range, a top speed of 90 mph, and 0 to 60 mph acceleration in 11.2 seconds. Whichever Soul you choose will be a long-lasting statement of individualism—and good thing a car like this is on the market.

New for 2015

Soul EV

pageElements.text:
Type: Minivan

Trim levels: L, LX, EX, SX, SX Limited
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 276 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): L, LX, EX: 18/24; SX: 18/25; SX Limited: 17/22 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good, all categories; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Front and rear controls for air conditioning
Notable standard features on this model: Side-N-Stow second-row seat function, third-row 60-40 split and sinking seating, YES Essentials seat fabric protection, Bluetooth connectivity, backup warning system
Notable options on this model: Surround-view camera, 19-inch alloy wheels, Nappa leather seating, power liftgate, heated front and second-row seats, ventilated front seats, second- and third-row sunshade, blind spot detection
You might also be considering: Chrysler Town & Country, Honda Odyssey, Toyota Sienna

The great design being practiced at Kia extends to the Sedona. From its bull nose to the spoiler that finishes the tapering roofline, this minivan shows some attitude. The Sedona is large (although at 201.4 inches, it’s only .8 inch longer than the K900 luxury sedan). Nevertheless, it steps off smartly thanks to the direct-injection 3.3-liter V-6, which makes 276 horsepower. A six-speed automatic transmission modulates the output. Seven-passenger seating is standard, with the Side-N-Stow second-row seat function included to make additional cargo room. Eight-passenger seating is optional in the LX and SX, standard in the EX. Trim levels range from the L, which is basic without being a monk’s cell, to the rather opulent Limited. A wood-trimmed, heated steering wheel and Nappa leather contribute to the interior’s distinctiveness, power side doors and liftgate are included, and 19-inch wheels suggest a formidable paw print. Smart cruise control is available on the Limited. Both the SX and Limited come with a 110-volt inverter in the console zone, letting you plug in a laptop. The Limited has a second inverter in the rear cargo area. The Sedona’s design, engineering, and product development team have done a great job with the new minivan. All entries in this segment are quite comparable in specifications and feature content, but crisp body lines give the Sedona an edge.

New for 2015

This all-new model was introduced last fall.

title: 2015 Kia Cadenza
subTitle: Near luxury, far cries of satisfaction.
promoTeaserSmall: Near luxury, far cries of satisfaction.
promoTeaser: Near luxury, far cries of satisfaction.
metaDescription: Near luxury, far cries of satisfaction. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan
Price range: $35,725–$44,625 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Premium, Limited
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 293 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 19/28 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good overall; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: not rated
Our favorite standard feature: 10-way adjustable driver’s seat
Notable standard features on this model: Leather-wrapped steering wheel, perimeter approach lighting, 8-inch navigation screen
Notable options on this model: Technology package, luxury package, sunroof, HID headlamps with “dynamic bending light,” heated rear outboard seats
You might also be considering: Buick LaCrosse, Ford Taurus, Chevrolet Impala

If not for the 293-horsepower V-6 and standard paddle shifters for manual control of the six-speed automatic transmission, we would say the Kia Cadenza is a purely sensible car, a nice value for the prudent consumer. But the direct-injection engine is potent, and those paddle shifters are pretty sporty. While you’re not falling too far behind the more renowned sport sedans on the road, you’ll be smiling about all the standard equipment at your fingertips. With a 10-way power-adjustable heated leather driver’s seat and seven-inch driver information display, the Cadenza Premium is well stocked with creature comforts.

A host of driver assistance and safety systems are standard, and a seven-inch TFT display and a heated steering wheel are optional. The Cadenza Limited adopts those features as standard and adds all sorts of additional niceties, from timekeeping (an exclusive analog clock) and interior lighting to additional driver-assistance features like lane keeping, blind-spot detection, and smart cruise control. The Limited also includes ventilated front seats and heated outboard rear seats with Nappa leather trim. The steering wheel’s position is power-adjustable as well. It’s hard to find fault with the Cadenza. The interior is huge, yet the car has a reasonable footprint and looks quite sleek and smart, if somewhat anonymous. What it lacks is razzle-dazzle, the glossy reputation of a BMW, but for some folks, that’s just fine.

New for 2015

Front grille, surround view monitor, panoramic sunroof, eight-way power front passenger seat, available rear cross-traffic alert and other driver assistance features.

Fuel economy (mpg): Sedan: 1.8-liter manual: 25/37; 1.8-liter automatic: 26/39; 2.0-liter automatic: 25/36 (city/highway)
Coupe: 2.0-liter manual: 24/33; 1.6-liter manual: 22/29; 2.0-liter automatic: 25/34; 1.6-liter automatic: 22/30 (city/highway)
Hatchback: 1.6-liter: 21/29; 2.0-liter automatic: 25/33 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good overall, marginal, small front overlap; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating (sedan), hatchback and coupe not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth connectivity
Notable standard features on this model: Steering-wheel-mounted audio controls, satellite radio, power-operated heated side mirrors.
Notable options on this model: Cruise control, remote keyless entry and power trunk release, 17- and 18-inch inch alloy wheels, heated and ventilated front and rear seats, cooling glove box, leather upholstery.
You might also be considering: Honda Civic, Hyundai Elantra, Nissan Sentra

The Kia Forte model range includes a sedan; the Forte5, a four-door hatchback; and a coupe called the Koup. The most basic LX sedan includes a 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine making 145 horsepower and a six-speed manual transmission. A six-speed automatic is optional, and it brings the best fuel economy of 39 highway mpg. The Forte LX has some key features like satellite radio, Bluetooth, power windows, and air conditioning. To this basic, inexpensive starting point, you can add a touchscreen, 16-inch alloy wheels, and a backup camera. Moving to the EX model, you find options packages that can give the car many unexpected luxury features. We do love a heated steering wheel. Heated and ventilated seats are available, too. The Koup is sporty, with the 2.0-liter and six-speed manual as standard but a powerful turbocharged 1.6-liter and an available automatic transmission with paddle shifters. EX and SX trim levels are offered, and the EX includes a leather-wrapped steering wheel and LED positioning lamps. Available eighteen-inch alloy wheels give the Koup an aggressive stance. Many of the sedan’s more premium options are found here in both trim levels. Sharing the Koup’s powertrain selection, the Forte5 is a handsome and more upscale four-door hatchback. Meanwhile, with up to 23.2 cubic feet of cargo capacity, the 5 adds a measure of utility to the lineup without sacrificing sportiness.

New for 2015

Improved fuel economy for the sedan.

title: 2015 Kia Optima
subTitle: Boldly striking forth.
promoTeaserSmall: Boldly striking forth.
promoTeaser: Boldly striking forth.
metaDescription: Boldly striking forth. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan
Price range: $22,515–$36,325 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, EX, SX, SX Turbo, SXL Turbo, Hybrid, Hybrid EX
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 192 horsepower; 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 274 horsepower, 2.4-liter four-cylinder/electric hybrid, 199 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 2.4-liter: 23/34; 2.0-liter: 20/31; Hybrid: 36/40; Hybrid EX: 35/39 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, head restraints & seats) and acceptable (small overlap front); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Brake assist system
Notable standard features on this model: Satellite radio, 6-speaker stereo, cooling glove box, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, cruise control, driver assistance features
Notable options on this model: Power folding mirrors, panoramic sunroof, rearview camera
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Toyota Camry

In a competitive market segment, the Kia Optima stands out because of its great design. It’s more daring, slightly larger, and somehow more premium-looking than most. We do a double-take whenever we see one. In addition to the Optima’s good looks, there’s a powertrain and trim level for everybody. The LX, EX, and SX have the direct-injection 2.4-liter four-cylinder that puts out 192 horsepower and gets 34 highway mpg. The SX and SXL Turbos have the turbocharged, direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 274 horsepower. The Hybrid and Hybrid EX combine the 2.4-liter four-cylinder with an electric drive system that incorporates a 47-kilowatt lithium-polymer battery. Each of the above cars uses a six-speed automatic. The LX is equipped with fog lamps, heated side mirrors, satellite radio, Bluetooth connectivity, a six-way power driver’s seat, and a package of electronically controlled safety and assistance features. The UVO2 eServices infotainment system is optional. The Hybrid’s standard equipment is much like that of the LX, while the Hybrid EX adds the infotainment system, rearview camera, and heated steering wheel. Climbing the trim level ladder to the SXL Turbo, we arrive at an elevated refuge of luxury of convenience, represented by a heated flat-bottom steering wheel with unique stitching, seats trimmed with Nappa leather trim, black gloss accents throughout the interior. Specified this way, it’s one of the ultimate choices available among front-drive midsize sedans.

New for 2015

UVO2 eServices infotainment system now offers Geo Fencing, Driving Score, Speed Alert, and Curfew Alert functions. Cruise control buttons are repositioned on the steering wheel, an acoustic laminated windshield is offered in all models, and white stitching is included on the SXL’s leather-wrapped steering wheel.

More about the Kia Optima

2016 Kia Optima at the New York Auto Show April 2, 2015

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan, hatchback
Price range: $14,815–$19,115 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, EX, SX
Engine: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmissions: 6-speed manual, 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 27/37; 1.6-liter with ISG: 28/37 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: marginal (small overlap front), good (moderate overlap front, roof strength, head restraints & seats), and average (side); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 overall rating, with safety concerns noted
Our favorite standard feature: Direct-injection engine
Notable standard features on this model: Stability control, hill start assist, steering-wheel-mounted audio controls, 60/40 split-folding rear seats
Notable options on this model: Pushbutton start, Bluetooth connectivity, UVO2 infotainment system
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Spark, Ford Fiesta, Honda Fit, Nissan Versa

Because of its light weight and the sporty direct-injection 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, the Kia Rio provides peppy performance to go with its interesting design. The Rio 5-Door hatchback, in particular, is eye-catching, with a wide-set wagon-like stance. While the Rio is cheap, it has merits beyond what’s under the hood. While conventional in every way, the interior is also attractively designed and laid out. The woven cloth upholstery of the LX improves to knit in the EX and leather in the SX. Power windows and locks along with remote keyless entry and Bluetooth connectivity are optional in the LX and standard in the other two. Antilock brakes, stability control, and hill-start assist are standard through the range. Standard in the sedan and 5-door is a rear defroster, and the 5-door adds standard heated, power-operated mirrors. If you’re looking for heated seats and steering wheel, you’ll have to move up to the SX. The Rio has become more refined, and in doing so it proves that spirited performance and good design can be available to penny pinchers.

New for 2015

Silverstone beige exterior paint is no longer offered

title: 2015 Kia K900
subTitle: Nailing luxury.
promoTeaserSmall: Nailing luxury.
promoTeaser: Nailing luxury.
metaDescription: Nailing luxury. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan
Price range: $55,400–$60,800 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Premium, Luxury
Engine: 5.0-liter V-8, 420 horsepower
Transmission: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 15/23 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: N/A
Our favorite standard feature: 14-speaker sound system
Notable standard features on this model: Rear-seat USB charger, 9.2-inch navigation display, surround view camera
Notable options on this model: LED headlamps with Dynamic Bending feature, soft-close doors, quilted Nappa leather seats, 16-way driver’s seat, heated and ventilated front seats and heated rear outboard seats
You might also be considering: Infiniti Q70, Lexus LS, Mercedes-Benz S-Class

Kia built a Lexus? So we asked upon grasping the heated, wood-trimmed steering wheel in the Kia K900. It drives with dreamy smoothness, like a Lexus, yet issues a muted snarl from the exhaust when the gas pedal gets stomped. The 5.0-liter V-8 generates 420 horsepower, which is transmitted through an advanced eight-speed automatic. Three driving modes—Eco, Normal, Sport, —govern the big 4555-pound sedan’s behavior. The K900 is more than just a case of an existing car being endowed with a lot of gadgets. It’s 200.6 inches long and rather tall-shouldered, so that the 19-inch wheels don’t seem at all too large. In our driveway, it looked stately and prepossessing. The fact that it’s so well equipped for the price seems miraculous. There are two models, Premium and Luxury, sharing the same powertrain. The Premium comes with all the important stuff like illuminated door scuff plates and a power-operated rear sunshade, but the Luxury pursues overkill with an optional 12.3-inch instrument cluster, soft-close doors, and head-up display. As standard features, it adds key safety features (blind spot detection, rear cross traffic alert) and makes smart cruise control optional. A particular delight is the available quilted Nappa leather seat trim. And wait till you see the complexity of the clock that’s mounted in a dashboard. Details and craftsmanship, along with a sound grasp of the grand scheme, make Kia successful in its entry into the luxury segment.

New for 2015

The K900 is a new model this year.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Price range: $22,990–$32,780 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: LX, Limited, S, C
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 184 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 295 horsepower
Transmission: 9-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): I-4: 23/36; V-6 FWD: 19/32; V-6 AWD: 18/29 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration 5/5 stars overall rating; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus
Our favorite standard feature: 7-inch vehicle information display
Notable standard features on this model: 9-speed automatic transmission
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, but only with the V-6 engine
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry

As we said during our "Should You Buy It?" test of the 2016 Chrysler 200, the number-one attraction of this mid-size Chrysler is the chance to get it with all-wheel drive. But close behind that, you'll find the looks are appealing as well. The mid-size sedan category is loaded with likely candidates. This one has the advantage of being big enough for the family, yet stylish enough to be your personal space.

Ideally, you'll go for the V-6 engine, which makes an invigorating 295 horsepower, over the 184-horsepower four-cylinder. That's unless fuel economy is a more important consideration: the four-cylinder gets you 36 mpg on the highway, nothing to sneeze at.

Chrysler's Uconnect infotainment system is clean, intuitive, and effective. The standard screen is five inches, but you can get an 8.4-inch screen with HD radio and navigation ($895). There are a few other options that will greatly improve your quality of life; we recommend in particular the optional dual-material leather and fabric seats with heating and ventilation, available on the S and C models ($995).

New for 2016

Heated steering wheel standard (200C)
Rearview camera standard (Limited and S)
Limited model options now include 3.6-liter V-6, blind spot monitoring, and rear cross-path detection
Three new exterior paint colors: Black Forest Green and Maximum Steel Clear Coat, and Redline Tri-Coat Pearl Coat

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The Buick Avista Concept, making its debut the night before the media preview at Detroit, just may have been the star of the show. In this designer walkaround the next day, Buick exterior design manager Chip Thole gave me the details on what the designers were thinking in sculpting this beauty. I'll just leave you with my final question to him from the video:
"Make this car, OK?"

title: Rain-X Latitude Wiper Blades
subTitle: New wiper blades are a cheap fix to your quality of life. Bonus: These give you Rain-X on tap.
promoTeaserSmall: New wiper blades are a cheap fix to your quality of life. Bonus: These give you Rain-X on tap.
promoTeaser: New wiper blades are a cheap fix to your quality of life. Bonus: These give you Rain-X on tap.
metaDescription: New wiper blades are a cheap fix to your quality of life. Bonus: These give you Rain-X on tap.

pageElements.text: Are you the kind of person who takes the time to apply paste wax, tire cleaner, and Armor All to your car? Using Rain-X is a little less fastidious than that, but not by much. The bright yellow bottle has a magic fluid that makes your windshield water repellent. It's cheap and easy; it really works. What's to stop you from using it?
Convenience, perhaps?

Here's a potential workaround: Rain-X offers a two-pronged solution, so to speak, with a set of Latitude replacement windshield wipers that add Rain-X water repellent solution to your windshield as you use the wipers. Metal parts are on the inside, meaning that only plastic is touching your windshield. That's a bonus because it makes the wipers less likely to freeze to your windshield in icy weather.

Unfortunately, installing replacement wipers can be an arcane and irritating business. That starts with the fact that there are so many different sizes, and several different ways the wipers attach to different vehicles. Is yours a J-hook, large pin, or small pin arm? Figure out which size and type is right for your car from Rain-X's website or at your local auto parts store.

A pair of these wipers costs around $35; each blade is sold separately.

I used the foolproof installation plan of pulling in my teenage son, who treated it like a puzzle. A quick look at the blades and the installation instructions, and we were in business. Once you have the remarkably flexible curved blades installed, you remove the yellow wiper covers from each wiper, then—starting with a clean, dry windshield—turn on the wipers and let them wipe the dry windshield for two to three minutes. After that, you spray a bit of your windshield wiper fluid, and the Rain-X you've installed with the blades becomes active.
Rain-X recommends replacing your wipers every Groundhog Day. Weird, but a good way to remember.

Rain-X recommends replacing your wipers every Groundhog Day. Weird, but a good way to remember. The only problem with that is for us Northerners who don't fancy struggling with wiper replacement in 5-degree weather. But it is an excellent way to make sure you are at Peak Wiper when April showers arrive. No matter when you do it, once or twice a year is not too often to give yourself a better look at the road by replacing blades.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

I had never met Stuart Norris, managing director of General Motors Korea Design, before doing this walkaround at the Detroit auto show. (He only looked slightly nervous.) In this video walkaround, he made his point that the Bolt is not just an EV, but also a versatile everyday car, with its flat load floor—thanks to a well-designed battery pack—and its 200 miles of range on a charge. That's without mentioning the spacious center console that looks big enough to hold a purse, and the big 10.2-inch touchscreen that will support Android Auto and Apple CarPlay. The Bolt goes into production later this year.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dSrcN_H_MO0?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

This is the third-generation Honda Pilot. It has a sleek new body, a lot of new stuff in the interior, a powerful new engine, and new six-speed and nine-speed automatic transmissions. For 2016, the Pilot also gets top safety and crash ratings from both the federal government and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
So let's count down the five coolest things about the 2016 Honda Pilot.

1. This unique transmission controller with fingertip control. It's like nothing I've ever seen before. You can use it without looking because each of the gear selectors is a different shape and feel, so you instantly know where you are.

2. An available intelligent traction management system adjusts traction to improve handling across all kinds of terrain. Extra cool points for the Sand, Mud, and Snow animations swirling around the icon of the Pilot, depending on which mode you check with this button. God, I love this, especially the Sand one.

3. This back-seat passenger paradise. I might occasionally give up the driver's seat to experience these second-row heated captain's chairs, especially if we add in the nine-inch rear entertainment screen that plays BluRay discs. I might just hire a chauffeur.

4. The Pilot is very serious about this whole luxury lounge vibe for the wayback third-row passengers, too. It begins with one-touch walk-through. That makes it a lot easier to get back there. And once you're settled, the panorama sunroof lets the sun shine in.

5. Now this is really cool. With all the seats up and a bench instead of these captain's chairs, the Pilot will hold eight passengers. And there's a cargo area under this little floor that will hold an eighty-two-quart mega cooler without moving the third row.
So get used to being the official party vehicle of your neighborhood.
Pick your own cool things about the new Pilot at automobiles.honda.com/pilot.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/CZP7eQ2c-ng?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

If you love new technology, you'll appreciate Honda moving into the future, bringing Honda Sensing, a suite of advanced safety technologies, to cars for the people. Four Hondas offer Honda Sensing; we have three of them here. And some of the individual features are available as stand-alone options across a variety of new Hondas.
So, here are my picks for Honda Sensing's five coolest features.

1. Adaptive cruise control is a foundation technology. The future of autonomous cars is based on this important tech, using cruise control to help monitor and automatically adjust your place on the Earth in relationship to the car in front of you—always helping to keep you at a safe distance.

2. Forward collision warning uses a small camera mounted at the top of the front windshield to monitor vehicles in front of you. If you do nothing when forward collision warning sends you an alert, in comes...

3. Automatic braking. That's the function of collision mitigation braking, as in, "Don't make me have to stop this car for you!" Collision mitigation braking uses a millimeter wave radar sensor and front-mounted camera to help bring your Honda to a stop when the system determines that a collision is unavoidable.

4. Road departure mitgation works on roads with solid lane markings indicating the outer edge of a roadway, left or right. If your vehicle drifts too close to a solid line without your turn signal on, your steering wheel will vibrate like crazy, and if that doesn't get your attention, it will use your steering to pull you back in the lane.

5. Lane departure warning and its buddy, lane keeping assist, are for the wanderers out there. Lane departure warning can read solid and dashed lane markings, and it doesn't like it when you change lanes without signaling. It beeps and it flashes to get your attention until you go back where you belong.
As its name suggests, lane keeping assist is more serious. If you begin to drift out of the center of the lane without using the turn signal, it will automatically steer you right back to center.
Find videos and more Honda Sensing safety technologies at automobiles.honda.com/sensing.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/3mg9CQULbew?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Welcome to the 2016 Honda Civic. Thirty-five million people worldwide have bought Civics. You may be surprised to find out that Honda is offering Honda Sensing on the new Civic, which will basically give the Civic all the cameras and radar that drivers will wonder how they ever lived without.
This is the tenth-generation Civic. It is back, and it's better than ever.

1. There's an all-new 1.5-liter four-cylinder engine for EX-T level Civics and above. This is the first turbocharged engine available on a U.S. Honda, and it makes 174 horsepower, which is more than any Civic that wasn't a performance Si model. Is there anything cooler than more horsepower?
2. This is clearly the time to call out the heated rear seats. Are you feeling the Civic yet? It's all grown up.

3. Remote engine start has come to Civic, and I'm sending this one back to the family and friends back home up North. Stay in your house, drinking your coffee in your jammies, and watch the snow come down. Then point your key fob out the window, watch for the headlights to flash, you'll see the engine come on, take another sip of coffee while your car warms up. This is worth its weight in gold, people.

4. Rain-sensing wipers. They've never been on a Civic before. No more turn the wipers on, wait three swipes, turn them off. They know what to do and when to do it. Available to those of you willing to spring for the Touring model.
5. I saved this for last. The Civic's exterior styling is so dramatic, I just want to let the camera give it the close-up it deserves.
Pick your own cool things about the new Civic at automobiles.honda.com/10th-gen-civic.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/VcU35bOkm68?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

There's a reason Honda builds minivans. People still want them, and not just big families. There are so many thoughtful features on the 2016 Honda Odyssey that picking five cool things barely scratches the surface.

1. The Odyssey's flexible console may be the coolest thing of all. There's a deep bin that will hold a purse. The top is a fast-food marvel. It will hold four drinks and a typical takeout tray. The flip-up trash ring holds a trash bag, and the whole thing moves out of the way so you can pass through. Don't tell me you're not impressed.
2. The multi-angle camera gives you an amazing live overhead view of your Odyssey as you maneuver neatly into tight parking spots. There's the normal view, and then there's the wide-angle view.
3. Blind-spot information is a godsend. A bright yellow icon fires up at your side mirror when the Odyssey's radar spots a car in your blind spot.

4. I am crazy about smart entry. As long as you have this key anywhere near you—like you can keep that lost in your big purse—you don't need it to lock or unlock the door. You just use this button on the door handle, press it once, it beeps once, you're locked.
To get back in, wait for two beeps; it's open. Smart indeed.
5. The Odyssey's ultra-wide rear entertainment system is huge, more than sixteen inches wide. I'm so jealous! I never get to enjoy this because I'm always the driver.
Pick your own cool things about the Odyssey at automobiles.honda.com/odyssey.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MmQumdw_kCQ?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
The Honda Accord is one of America's most respected sedans. It has won thirty Car and Driver 10 Best awards in its lifetime, more than any other car.
The 2016 Accord offers the premium Honda Sensing suite of advanced driver assist technologies that help assist the driver to stay on the road, in the lane, and out of trouble.
The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has given the Accord its top safety rating for crashworthiness: the Top Safety Pick Plus.
Here are the Five Cool Things you'll find on the 2016 Accord.

1. At the top of my hit list, for the first time in a Honda, is Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, the ultimate smartphone connectivity, offering you seamless, hands-free connection to your phone, your music, and some of your favorite apps. All of that coming through a nice big touchscreen display so you're looking forward at your touchscreen instead of down at your phone.

2. There's a V-6 engine in the Touring edition. Honda didn't have to put a V-6 in the Accord. This category typically uses a turbocharged four-cylinder engine for a power boost. I'd rather have a V-6, and this one has 278 horsepower. It sounds great, it's responsive, and it has soul. It also has a six-speed automatic transmission that helps it get 34 miles per gallon on the highway.

3. Not only does the Accord have a multi-angle rearview camera, which gives you a choice of three different backup views, it has LaneWatch, which is one more camera that shows you live video of the right lane when you flip on your right turn signal. It's perfect for going around tight turns but also for seeing that big rig roaring up on you just as you're about to change lanes on the freeway.
4. The Accord already has a huge trunk, but now there's also a 60/40 folding rear seat. There's a release on each side, basically turning this thing into a mini-ute.
And the split seat accommodates the long load and a passenger at the same time.
5. Do you like your back-seat passengers? Well, you can now give the two outboard passengers heated seats. Share the love! The middle-seat passenger: still out of luck.
Pick your own cool things about the Accord at automobiles.honda.com/accord.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/aeeaRrplkE8?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Try to tell an Odyssey family that minivans aren't cool. They'll laugh in your face while they're drinking their chilled beverages from their oh-so-cool cool boxes and vacuuming up the spilled cereal with their built-in vacuum.
There are so many thoughtful features on the 2016 Honda Odyssey that picking five cool things barely scratches the surface.

1. The cool box will fit six eight-ounce cans or four twenty-ounce bottles. It's not a fridge that chills warm beverages but a compartment that uses the Odyssey's air conditioning to keep cold beverages from getting warm.
2. Bluetooth and streaming audio are now standard across all Odyssey trim levels. It's the best way to listen to the tunes stored on your phone.
3. Pair your compatible phone, and you'll be able to receive text messages that will be read to you. And you'll be able to send one of six preprogrammed replies. It lets you stay connected.

4. The third-row Magic Seat. This is for families who need maximum cargo without removing the third row and storing it in the garage. One strap. Pull it down; the seat stows just like that. It's faster than power and creates a flat load floor. Magic.
5. I saved the best for last. I was not kidding about that vacuum. It's built in, and it will pretty much pick up that cereal anywhere it lays.
Pick your own cool things about the Odyssey at automobiles.honda.com/odyssey.

title: 2016 Kia Forte and Forte5
subTitle: As a hatchback or a sedan, this is a lot of little car for a little money.
promoTeaserSmall: As a hatchback or a sedan, this is a lot of little car for a little money.
promoTeaser: As a hatchback or a sedan, this is a lot of little car for a little money.
metaDescription: As a hatchback or a sedan, this is a lot of little car for a little money.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive subcompact sedan, hatchback, or coupe
Price range: $16,840 – $20,840
Trim levels: LX, EX
Engines: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 145 horsepower (LX); 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 173 horsepower (EX)
Transmission: Six-speed manual (LX), six-speed automatic (LX, EX)
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/37 mpg highway (LX, manual); 26/39 mpg (LX, automatic); 24/35 mpg (EX, automatic)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars (sedan); 5/5 stars side crash, 4/5 stars rollover, no overall rating (hatchback); Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in four areas, Marginal in small overlap front crash testing
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth connectivity (standard on all models)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, leather-trimmed steering wheel, cooling glove box (standard on EX only)
Notable options on this model: Navigation with seven-inch touchscreen, sunroof, leather interior (EX Premium package, $3,000)
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Hyundai Elantra, Toyota Corolla

The Kia Forte is the very embodiment of an entry-level car: priced right starting under $17,000, it still comes standard with Bluetooth, keyless entry, and the basic amenities such as power-adjustable seats and power windows, meaning it's far from stripped down. The Forte is available in two body styles, hatchback and sedan; the Forte Koup was discontinued after the 2015 model year. There's even a sporty SX version of the Forte hatchback, featuring 201 horsepower from a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, paired with a standard six-speed manual transmission, and still coming in under $22,000. If you spring for the $3,000 EX Premium package—which will bring the total price up close to $25,000—you'll get such higher-end features as heated and ventilated seats, a seven-inch touchscreen with navigation, and a sunroof. On the savings end of the scale, the base LX will cost $1,000 more with automatic transmission, but it also edges close to the holy grail of 40 mpg with its 39-mpg highway numbers.

The Forte comes up against strong competition in the subcompact segment: the Honda Civic, Mazda 3, Ford Focus, Toyota Corolla, and many others. That ten-year, 100,000-mile warranty from Kia should be part of the argument for considering this car. Another is its good looks and reasonable interior space, falling only slightly short of the Honda Civic's. And a third is that a six-speed manual transmission is standard on the base Forte LX sedan and the Forte SX hatchback. That's increasingly hard to find.

Related story: Cars with Manual Transmissions You Can Buy Now

New for 2016

Forte LX gets four new colors, remote keyless entry, and rearview camera
Forte EX gets rearview camera and seventeen-inch alloy wheels
Navigation available on Forte EX (Premium package, $) Forte Koup is discontinued

title: 2016 Kia K900
subTitle: The top echelon of luxury from a refreshingly different source.
promoTeaserSmall: The top echelon of luxury from a refreshingly different source.
promoTeaser: The top echelon of luxury from a refreshingly different source.
metaDescription: The top echelon of luxury from a refreshingly different source.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive luxury sedan
Price range: $49,950 – $62,850 (includes destination)
Trim levels: V-6 Premium, V-6 Luxury, V-8 Luxury
Engine: 3.8-liter V-6, 311 horsepower; 5.0-liter V-8, 420 horsepower
Transmission: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 17 mpg city/28 mpg highway (V-6); 15/23 mpg (V-8 models)
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Heated and ventilated front seats
Notable standard features on this model: LED lighting, 9.2-inch high-definition touchscreen with navigation, panoramic sunroof with sun shade
Notable options on this model: LED headlamps with Dynamic Bending feature, soft-close doors, quilted Nappa leather seats, 16-way driver’s seat, ventilated rear seats (Luxury models)
You might also be considering: Infiniti Q70, Lexus LS, Mercedes-Benz S-Class

Kia has been making economy cars for a while now, but that does not imply that up here, in luxury-sedan territory, it can't build a car worthy of contending against the usual European and Japanese luxury suspects. The K900 is an impressive, and well-priced, alternative to those in the rear-wheel-drive luxury sedan category. It starts just under $50,000 and comes with a plethora of impressive safety and comfort features, from heated and ventilated front seats to gorgeous LED lighting. The K900 made its debut with a V-8, and that's still available, but this year a V-6 was added, making 311 horsepower and increasing fuel economy slightly, from 23 to 28 mpg on the highway.

The Luxury models get options such as a head-up display, quilted Nappa leather seating, premium nineteen-inch chrome wheels and tires, and advanced smart cruise control. V-8 Luxury models have standard rear cross-traffic alert and lane departure warning systems, while these two active safety features are available as options on the V-6 Luxury. Bragging rights with the neighbors are in the cards thanks to the Smart Power Trunk, which flips open the trunk if you've got the key fob within a few feet of the deck lid for more than three seconds. Another new feature this year is Smart Shift and Drive, which puts you in Eco, Normal, or Sport mode automatically based on the way you're driving. Sort of a personal trainer for your commute.
Suffice it to say, if you want a rear-wheel-drive sedan that's luxurious yet interesting, this one merits a look.

New for 2016

All-new 3.8-liter V-6 engine is standard
Image upgrade with a new front grille, rear bumper, taillights, eighteen-inch wheels, and chrome trim
Paddle shifters
Automated Emergency Braking (V-6 and V-8 Luxury models)
Smart Shift and Drive
Automatic Smart Power Trunk (opens when key fob is nearby)
High-definition 9.2-inch touchscreen

title: 2016 Kia Sorento
subTitle: Beautiful and versatile.
promoTeaserSmall: Beautiful and versatile.
promoTeaser: Beautiful and versatile.
metaDescription: Beautiful and versatile.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five- or seven-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive mid-size crossover
Price range: $25,195-$42,595 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, EX, SX, SX Limited, Limited V6
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 191 horsepower; turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; 3.3-liter V-6, 290 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Sportmatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 2.4-liter FWD: 20 mpg city/27 mpg highway; 2.4-liter AWD: 19/25; V-6 FWD: 18/25; V-6 AWD: 18/24 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars overall; Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick
Our favorite standard feature: YES Essentials anti-stain fabric treatment
Notable standard features on this model: Front active headrests, hill start assist, stability control, second-row underfloor cargo storage
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, 19-inch wheels, programmable power liftgate, panoramic sunroof, second-row sliding sunshades, ventilated front seats
You might also be considering: Dodge Journey, Ford Edge, Toyota Highlander

The 2016 Kia Sorento has a new look, and that's important in a market segment with so much competition. How many crossovers, after all, can you look at before feeling a little overwhelmed (or bored)? The 2016 Sorento makes excellent use of LED lighting and body sculpting to catch your attention. There's also a new turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine making 240 horsepower, alongside a pair of other engine choices, a four-cylinder and a V-6. All are teamed with a six-speed automatic transmission. Interestingly, you can equip your Sorento with or without a third row of seats, giving you the choice whether to make it a five-passenger SUV or a seven-passenger.

The 2016 Sorento is slightly larger and roomier than the model it replaces: 3.1 inches longer in wheelbase, with 74 cubic feet of total cargo capacity, when seats are folded, versus 72.5 cubic feet in the past. That's on par with the Ford Edge (73.4 cubic feet) and a little better than the Honda CR-V (70.9 cubic feet).

New for 2016

2016 Sorento is an all-new model.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive luxury sedan
Trim levels: T5 (FWD), Momentum or Inscription; T6 (AWD), Momentum or Inscription
Prices: Not yet released
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 250 horsepower (T5); turbocharged and supercharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 316 horsepower (T6)
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Audi A6 Premium ($47,125)
2016 BMW 528i ($51,195)
2016 Mercedes-Benz E350 ($54,025)

You know Volvo as a safety-focused automaker, and one with timeless—some might say staid—design, and there is no better proof of both than its new flagship, the 2017 S90. The look is pure, and not a bit frumpy. On board is a full complement of the very latest semi-autonomous driving technology. The S90 premieres Volvo's second-generation Pilot Assist, which will be able to manage every aspect of your driving—steering, acceleration, deceleration, and braking—at speeds up to 80 mph, while the S90 remains under your control. The S90, on sale later this year, will be the first car on the U.S. market to offer this much semi-autonomous technology, and it will be standard on every S90.

Pilot Assist is already available on the critically acclaimed 2016 Volvo XC90, but that (first generation) version works only at speeds up to 30 mph. The S90 is available with front- or all-wheel drive, with a turbocharged four-cylinder engine making 240 horsepower or with a turbocharged and supercharged four-cylinder that makes 316 horsepower. A hybrid version is also in the works.

In this video, design manager Orjan Sterner points out some of the fine points.

title: 2016 Kia Rio
subTitle: A fresh face for the economy-minded subcompact.
promoTeaserSmall: A fresh face for the economy-minded subcompact.
promoTeaser: A fresh face for the economy-minded subcompact.
metaDescription: A fresh face for the economy-minded subcompact.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive subcompact sedan and hatchback
Price range: $15,015 – $21,605 (sedan); $16,345 – $21,755 (hatchback) (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, EX, SX
Engine: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual (sedan), six-speed automatic hatchback; optional on sedan)
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Marginal (small overlap front); Good (moderate overlap front, roof strength, head restraints & seats), and Acceptable (side); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars overall rating, with safety concerns noted
Our favorite standard feature: Direct-injection engine
Notable standard features on this model: Stability control, hill start assist, steering-wheel-mounted audio controls, 60/40 split-folding rear seats
Notable options on this model: Push-button start, Bluetooth connectivity, UVO2 infotainment system
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Spark, Ford Fiesta, Honda Fit, Nissan Versa

If you're looking for a bargain-priced, entry-level car, this is one of the more attractive offerings out there. Ante up a little more cash, and you can get the SX, with a sportier suspension, paddle shifters on the steering column, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel, plus uplevel amenities such as navigation, push-button start, a rearview camera, and a power sunroof.

The hatchback version, called the Rio Five-Door, is cuter than the sedan in our opinion. Both models, though, have their strong points. One in particular is the six-speed manual transmission in the Rio sedan, an increasingly hard-to-find feature these days (it was discontinued from the hatchback for 2016). You can get the sedan with an automatic at a $1,230 upcharge.

If you're truly looking for a cheap base model, you can't beat the LX with its under-$15,000 price, even though features modern car buyers take for granted, such as power windows and locks, keyless entry, and Bluetooth connectivity are all optional. The mid-level EX model adds those things, plus a Designer package, new for 2016, costs $750 and adds black-and-gray cloth and leather seat trim, with gray stitching throughout, and a 4.3-inch touchscreen and a rearview camera. A $600 Eco package, also for the EX, adds a stop/start system for fuel saving and some lighting and other interior upgrades.

New for 2016

The Kia Rio was updated for 2016, with the new model rolled out at the 2015 Chicago Auto Show.
New front and rear fascias update the look.
Two new colors: Urban Blue and Digital Yellow

title: 2016 Cadillac CT6 Platinum
subTitle: A princely sedan that takes Cadillac a step closer to full resurrection.
promoTeaserSmall: A princely sedan that takes Cadillac a step closer to full resurrection.
promoTeaser: A princely sedan that takes Cadillac a step closer to full resurrection.
metaDescription: A princely sedan that takes Cadillac a step closer to full resurrection.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive full-size luxury sedan
Base price: $65,390 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $88,460
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6, 404 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Bose Panaray audio with 34 speakers (Platinum model)
Option I can’t live without: Active Chassis Control (Platinum edition)
Notable standard features on this model: Active Chassis package (on Platinum model): Magnetic Ride Control, active rear steering, 20-inch wheels and tires; driver vision and assistance features (on Platinum model): Full-speed adaptive cruise control, side blind zone alert, rear cross-traffic alert, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, forward collision alert, following distance indicator, low-speed auto front and rear braking
Notable options on this model: Vision and Comfort package ($2,205): High-definition rearview camera in mirror, panoramic power sunroof, ventilated front seats, heated rear outboard seats
You might also be considering (prices include destination charge):
2016 Audi A8 L ($81,500)
2016 BMW 740i ($82,295)
2016 Jaguar XJ R-Sport ($75,395)
2016 Lexus LS460 ($73,470)

The golden age of Cadillac may have been a while ago, but the Cadillac name still does command respect, particularly with its recent sedan offerings. But not as much respect as Cadillac president Johan de Nysschen wants for GM’s top division, something that can be said for the entirety of General Motors management, from CEO Mary Barra on down.
The objective is to achieve parity—in performance and in public perception—with the dominators of the luxury-sedan market, specifically the Audi A8, BMW 7 Series, and Mercedes S-Class.
That’s the top rung in this class. Has the CT6 ascended to the heights?

In a way, the new Caddy begs that question. Although it supplants the XTS as the biggest of current Cadillac sedans, it’s a little smaller than the above-named German competitors in the full-size sedan category. On the other hand, it’s bigger than the mid-size four-doors like the Audi A6 and the BMW 5 Series.

The 2016 Cadillac CT6 is a handsomely furnished sedan with impressive dynamics, distinctive Cadillac good looks, and plenty of room. It’s not quite as voluminous as one of the high-end Germans—or, for that matter, a Jaguar XJ or a Lexus LS—but unless your personal dimensions qualify you for the NBA, space is plentiful. And the only issue for those in the stratospheric height category might be headroom. But that’s true for just about any sedan you care to name.

The CT6 is new from the ground up. The Platinum model we tested sits at the top of the CT6 lineup, and it includes everything from the option cupboard. The aluminum-intensive body shell is comparatively light for a car in this general category. The curb weight ranges from 3,657 to just over 4,000 pounds. A car weighing in at over two tons is obviously no sylph, but even so the CT6 is lighter than its top-end rivals.
The 2016 Cadillac CT6 is a handsomely furnished sedan with impressive dynamics, distinctive Cadillac good looks, and plenty of room.

Lighter is always a good thing in vehicle dynamics, especially when the formula includes high chassis rigidity—which is the case here. It also includes the availability of Cadillac’s magnetic ride control auto-adjusting suspension, as effective as any system going, and a new rear-steering feature that enhances handiness at parking lot speeds and amplifies confidence when the pace picks up.

There are three engine choices: a 265-horsepower 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder; a 335-hp 3.6-liter V-6 (non-turbo); and a new 404-hp 3.0-liter V-6 that includes start/stop technology (shuts itself down at stoplights) and cylinder deactivation (shuts down half the engine in light load cruising). All three engines are paired with a new eight-speed automatic transmission, and the V-6 models include all-wheel drive; the four-cylinder is rear-wheel-drive only.

The CT6 scores higher on this scale than any previous Cadillac, right down to the basic CT6 (which is a long way from basic). Materials are rich and tasteful—various woods, leather of course, tasteful décor treatments, hardly a hard surface in the entire car, beautiful electroluminescent instruments, a 10.2-inch screen in mid-dash for infotainment, navigation, audio control.
The Bose Panaray edition has thirty-four speakers, some of them under the floor. This system, visceral as well as auditory, must be experienced to be believed.

GM’s computer geeks have improved the Cadillac User Experience (CUE) touchscreen system—it needed it—and there are three Bose audio choices, culminating in the Panaray edition: thirty-four speakers, some of them under the floor. This system, visceral as well as auditory, must be experienced to be believed. It’s standard with the CT6 Platinum and a $3,700 option in the other trims. If someone like your humble narrator, his hearing diminished by too many years hanging around motor racing tracks, is seduced by this system, true audiophiles will perceive it as a bargain.

Other nifty features: the rear seats adjust fore and aft, the seatbacks recline, and there’s an available massage function. The available rear-seat infotainment system includes a pair of 10.2-inch screens morticed into the front-seat backs, and as noted there’s stretch-out legroom back there.

A new color head-up display helps the driver keep eyes on the road, there’s a camera integrated with the inside rearview mirror, and a new triggered video option allows the owner to record up to thirty-two hours of driving. This could well produce some of the most boring video in history—imagine a visual record of cruising I-80 across Nebraska—but could be useful in, say, accident documentation.

Demerits? The touchpad control located just ahead of the center armrest is a little behind the times, with gesture control coming into vogue, and its location isn’t ideal—the driver has to be careful about dangling fingers. The seats, although comfortable, could offer a little more lateral support in hard cornering, and the CT6 isn’t on the cutting edge of current developments on the road to autonomous driving—although change is near on that front.
But these are minor issues, heavily outweighed by plaudits.

For example, the sheetmetal surrounding the posh interior is yet another handsome expression of the bold Art and Science design language Cadillac established in 1999. It’s not as edgy as some interpretations of the discipline—the styling of many of these high-end sedans tends toward conservative—but the big egg-crate grille and waterfall LED running lights on the front fenders are unmistakably Cadillac.

Beyond that, the proportions are athletic and modern—long hood, suggesting plenty of power, short front overhang—not much car extending beyond the front wheels. The skin seems tightly wrapped, and the wheels extend right out to the edge of the fenders and fill up the wheel wells.

There are some who see the car’s rear end styling as a little underdone. I'm neutral about it, and so is the rear of this car. Is this a bad thing? Here’s the deal: when you pull up to the valet at Café Merveilleux, no one will be looking at the Caddy’s rear end.
The CT6 is distinctive and handsome, and like the German high rollers, it has an upscale presence. What else do you need?
When it comes to dynamics, carmakers seeking recognition in this league had better bring their A game, and the CT6 does just that.

When it comes to dynamics, carmakers seeking recognition in this league had better bring their A game, and the CT6 does just that—within power limits. Some models of the top German sedans bring heavyweight punch to the arena, 500 horsepower and more, not to mention diesels. But Cadillac’s new 3.0-liter turbo V-6 is capable of propelling the two-ton CT6 Platinum to 60 mph in about five seconds.
That’s not slow, and even the 2.0-liter moves briskly, thanks to its relatively modest mass.

However, the real virtues here are grace and agility, two traits the CT6 possesses in gratifying quantities. Body motions are nicely controlled in any of the three driving modes, steering is nicely weighted and dead-bang accurate, and even the basic CT6 is a willing companion on a twisty back road.

But the combination of the Active Chassis Control (with rear steering and magnetic ride), all-wheel drive, and the 3.0-liter twin-turbo lends real zeal to forward progress. The CT6 is one of those cars that inspires confidence at the first set of turns, nicely balanced, entertaining to drive, all-day comfortable, and quiet at all speeds on almost any surface.

The Verdict

As large cars go, the CT6 goes better than most, and holds its own with its target rivals on any grading scale—styling, content, execution, dynamics. And with a price ladder that ranges from $54,490 to $88,460, it barely overlaps the lower end of the price spectrum for the top German competitors. Johan de Nysschen says you can’t discount your way to prestige. But that’s not the CT6 story. Remember, at $88,460, the Platinum is all in—all the goodies.
It’s hard to think of cars in this general price range as bargains. But the CT6 has a case.

title: Toyo's Variable-Condition Tires
subTitle: Testing Toyo Celsius tires, part 1. Good in the winter, but you can keep them on all year? I'm in.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: You’ve heard of snow tires. You’ve heard of all-season tires. Now get ready for the variable condition tire, the Toyo Celsius. Not a pure snow or winter tire, but more than a traditional all-season tire, the Celsius is a true hybrid.

Toyo Celsius Tires

Type: Variable conditions
Variants: Celsius Passenger, Celsius CUV
Benefits: Warranty for 60,000 miles; 500-mile/45-day "no regrets" trial offer
Claimed to stop up to 14 feet shorter on snow and eight feet shorter on ice than an all-season tire
Celsius CUV tires claimed to stop up to 31 feet shorter on snow than an all-season tire

The asymmetrical tread design, Toyo says, will help the Celsius perform well, no matter what conditions Mother Nature throws at you. Although it’s intended for areas that don’t get a lot of snow but do deal with slush and rainfall, the Celsius still is intended to be an improvement over all-season tires. It has higher sipe density on the inside tread for ice and snow, and lower sipe density on the outside tread for wet and dry conditions.

The Toyo jargon includes talk of “snow claws” and “slush grooves,” but the bottom line is, this tire is built to handle snowy and wet conditions, yet still deliver a quiet ride. Best of all, these tires, unlike dedicated snow tires, are suitable for year-round driving.
All of that explains why I knocked over my colleagues to be the one to test them, and I currently have a set on my 2003 Volkswagen Passat.

I am a hard-core believer in snow tires. I live in Michigan and understand that tires are first responders in an emergency. Hopefully, they will help me avoid needing the airbags or any of the other safety equipment. But I am a huge procrastinator. I have been known to put on my snow tires in January and take them off in July. So a tire that I put on and leave on until the tread wears off is a hell-yes for me.
The beauty of the Toyo Celsius tire is that I can leave them on all year long, with no need to go back to the tire store until I need to rotate my tires.

The beauty of the Toyo Celsius tire is that I can leave them on all year long, with no need to go back to the tire store until I need to rotate my tires. When I would flip back and forth from summer to winter tires, I loathed the trip to get them changed,  and storing the off-season set in my cluttered garage was a hassle. Somehow, I always seemed to be at the store during a snowstorm with every other procrastinator, and a tire store is the very last place I want to be during Michigan’s micro summers.

Getting the Toyo Celsius tires in place was an education in itself. Here’s what I learned: If you’re interested in trying these, you’ll may have to special order them. This is a new product that you won’t find in every shop. In my case, UPS dropped off my tires. They came nude, no box, with the shipping label taped to the tire itself. That was when I realized I needed to find a place to actually install them. I have always bought my tires directly from the tire store. During the process, I have always felt rushed and overwhelmed. But coming in with my own tires and just needing the installation I felt more in charge.

When you buy tires directly from a retailer, the installation is much cheaper than the charge when you bring in your own tires. At my local store, Discount Tire in Ann Arbor, Michigan, the charge $64 ($16 per tire) to install tires that you purchase directly from them, which includes rotation and balancing for the life of the tire. I paid much more—$156—to have Discount Tire dismount my old tires, mount the Toyo Celsius tires I brought in, and balance them. Future rotation is included, but any balancing that might be needed in the future is not.

In the past, I never called and made an appointment; I just showed up and inevitably sat around for a few hours waiting for my turn. This time I made an appointment and was in and out in about forty minutes. I strongly suggest you do the same.

The process of getting my tires installed was like a symphony. There was a director behind a podium overseeing the process as the team scurried around and quickly removed my tires. It was a sloppy winter’s day, far past the prime time to slip on your winter shoes. I had thoughtfully washed my car before bringing it in to make the job a little nicer for the installers. As I watched them working together to move cars through at a pace that would make Henry Ford crack a smile, I thought that they deserved a heated floor.

The question of whether to buy your tires remotely or at a tire store comes down to economics. The cost from an online seller may be cheaper, but the cost of installation may offset those savings. I found the Celsius available online for $82 per tire, plus shipping. My local Discount Tire did not offer the tire so I cannot compare apples to apples, but it’s always important to compare not only price per tire, but installation charges.

So, should you count on shopping locally for tires? Consider the pros and cons, such as being able to research your tires on the Internet, take your pick from a much larger selection than you’ll find at a single store, and possibly get a price deal; all of that might outweigh the higher installation cost and the hassle factor of  getting tires mailed to you, then lugging them to the tire installer.

As for the tires, so far I am very pleased with the ride and the lack of noise—and I must admit that the very mild winter we’ve had so far has been an easy test environment for these “variable condition” tires. Conditions have been variable as hell in Michigan! Still, I am hoping for a big dump of snow like the one New England recently received to give the tires a real test. Fingers crossed that my next report on the Toyo Celsius will include the yet-to-be-named storm of the century.

Toyo Celsius tires as they arrived via UPS.
Discount Tire employees swarmed the car.
